Fig. 1 X-ray diffraction patterns of Pd@MnOx microspheres obtained using MnOx microspheres calcined at (A) 410 °C and (B) 500 °C. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 The chemical route followed for the synthesis of monodisperse-porous Pd@MnOx microspheres. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM photograph showing the size distribution of Pd NPs at (A) 50 nm scale and (B) 20 nm scale. (C) The variation of zeta potential of Pd NPs with pH. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 SEM photographs showing the size distribution and surface morphology of Pd@Mn5O8microspheres. Magnification: (A) X2.500, (B) X25.000, (C) X45.000, (D) X100.000. TEM-EDS mapping photographs of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres showing (E) carbon, palladium, manganese and oxygen, (F) palladium, (G) mangenese, (H) oxygen. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 SEM photographs showing the size distribution and surface morphology of (A) Pd@SiO2 and (B) Pd@TiO2 microspheres. Magnification: (A-1) X2.500, (A-2) X25.000, (A-3) X38.000, (A-4) X100.000, (B-1) X2.500, (B-2) X25.000, (B-3) X45.000, (B-4) X100 .000. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 The pore size distribution curves of Pd@SiO2, Pd@TiO2 and Pd@MnOx microspheres obtained by nitrogen adsorption and desorption method. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Survey XPS spectra of (A) MnO2, (B) Mn5O8, (C) APTES@Mn5O8, (D) Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres and (E) Core level spectrum for Pd3d scan of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 BzOH conversion, BzCHO selectivity and BzCHO formation yield obtained with Pd@SiO2, Pd@TiO2, plain Mn5O8 and Pd@MnOx microspheres as the catalyst in BzOH oxidation. Conditions: Initial BzOH concentration: 100 mM, TBHP concentration: 150 mM, Catalyst concentration: 8 mg/mL, Volume: 10 mL, Temperature: 80 °C, Time: 4 h, Stirring rate: 400 rpm. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Core-level XPS spectra of Mn2p scan for (A) MnO2, (B) Mn5O8, (C) APTES@Mn5O8, (D) Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The mechanism proposed for the synergistic catalytic activity obtained with Pd@MnOx microspheres in BzOH oxidation. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 The effect of (A) initial BzOH concentration, (B) catalyst amount, (C) Pd NP loading, and (D) TBHP concentration on BzOH conversion, BzCHO selectivity and BzCHO formation yield obtained by Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres. Common conditions: TBHP concentration: 150 mM, Catalyst concentration: 8 mg/mL, Pd loading: 2.5 % w/w, Volume: 10 mL, Temperature: 80 °C, Time: 4 h, Stirring rate: 400 rpm. Except for the variable condition, the other conditions are identical with those given above unless otherwise stated in each case. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 BzOH conversion, BzCHO selectivity and BzCHO formation yield values obtained in the repeated use of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres in BzOH oxidation. Conditions: Initial BzOH concentration: 100 mM, TBHP concentration: 150 mM, Catalyst concentration: 8 mg/mL, Volume: 10 mL, Temperature: 80 °C, Time: 6 h, Stirring rate: 400 rpm. Graphical abstract A heterogeneous catalyst for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol (BzOH) was synthesized by immobilization of Pd nanoparticles (Pd NPs, 3 nm) on monodisperse-porous manganese oxide (MnOx, 4 μm) microspheres obtained by “staged shape templating protocol”. MnOx microspheres containing Mn5O8 (97 %) and MnO2 (78 %) phases were evaluated as supports. The catalysts carrying immobilized Pd NPs were also synthesized, using monodisperse-porous SiO2 and TiO2 microspheres with similar size and porous properties (i.e. Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2). Pd NP decorated-Mn5O8 (Pd@Mn5O8) microspheres provided the highest catalytic activity with BzOH conversion of 92.2 % and benzaldehyde (BzCHO) selectivity of 96.3 %. Higher catalytic activity of Pd@Mn5O8 was explained by mixed valence nature of Mn5O8 microspheres assisting the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies. Mn (II), Mn(III) and Mn(IV) oxidation states were shown by deconvoluted x-ray photoelectron spectra. A synergistic catalytic activity was reported for the first time, by combination of Pd NPs with Mn5O8 microspheres. Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres could be reused up to 5 times without remarkable loss in the activity and selectivity towards BzCHO. A methodology for comparison of catalytic activity and synergistic interaction between active site and support was also exemplified by choosing a nanoparticle type and a monodisperse-porous microsphere type. Keywords Manganese oxide Silica Titania Porous microspheres Oxygen spillover 1 Introduction There is a great effort to carry out oxidation of benzyl alcohol (BzOH) in the aqueous phase by using molecular oxygen [1], hydrogen peroxide [2] or t-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) [3] as the oxidant [4,5]. Noble metal nanoparticles (NPs) such as Pt, Pd, Au were used as efficient catalysts due to the quantum size effect and high ratio of surface area to volume in alcohol oxidation reactions [6,7]. Among these noble metal catalysts, Pd shows relatively high activity and selectivity in BzOH oxidation [8–10]. However, the reusability of noble metal nanoparticles is not possible due to their low stability and low catalytic activity because of aggregation [10,11]. Therefore to overcome such problems, the metal nanoparticles are immobilized on various transition metal oxide based supports such as cerium dioxide [10,12], aluminum oxide [8,13], and titanium dioxide [14]. On the other hand, manganese oxide (MnOx) nanostructures immobilized on different supports and MnOx based supports have been used due to their unique properties such as high activity, low cost and nontoxicity in alcohol oxidation with high catalytic activity and selectivity [15–21]. Tan et al. synthesized Pd NP supported manganese oxide–carbon nanotube hybrid nanomaterials (MnOx-CNT) by facile depositing method and examined the catalytic activity of nanocatalyst by the oxidation of BzOH using molecular oxygen [17]. Assal et al. established a method for the synthesis of MnO2 nanocomposites decorated with Ag NPs and used them in the oxidation of alcohols in the presence of oxygen [18]. Alshammari et al. synthesized Au-Pd supported MnO2 nanoalloy catalysts and investigated their catalytic activity by the oxidation of BzOH [19]. Hutchings et al. hydrothermally synthesized MnO2 microspheres containing nanowires and used as supports for immobilization of Au NPs. Furthermore, they investigated the catalytic activity of MnO2 nanowire microspheres decorated with Au NPs for the solvent-free oxidation of BzOH [20]. Chen et al. synthesized MnOx/Pd catalysts by atomic layer deposition of MnOx on Pd/Al2O3 catalysts formed by wet impregnation and used MnOx/Pd catalysts in the benzyl alcohol oxidation [21]. In recent years, heterogenous catalysts containing metal nanoparticles immobilized on various supports like graphene [22], carbon [23,24], SiO2 [25], TiO2 [26,27], CeO2 [28] and others [29–32] have been tried in BzOH oxidation since it is known that the interaction between the support material and metal NPs determines the catalytic activity. In the literature, some similar hybrid nanostructures containing metal nanoparticles have also been synthesized and used as oxidation catalysts in selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol [33–37] and organic molecule synthesis [38–43]. Recently, a staged shape templating protocol based on the hydrothermal decomposition of KMnO4 on polymethacrylate microspheres was developed for the synthesis of monodisperse-porous MnOx microspheres [44]. The crystalline properties of synthesized microspheres were changed by adjusting the calcination temperature. In this study, the catalysts for selective oxidation of BzOH to BzCHO under atmospheric pressure were synthesized by the immobilization of Pd NPs onto MnOx microspheres containing predominantly MnO2 or Mn5O8 phases. Similar catalysts were also obtained by the immobilization of Pd NPs onto monodisperse-porous SiO2 and TiO2 microspheres with similar size and porous properties. The catalytic performances of MnOx based catalysts were comparatively investigated using SiO2 and TiO2 microsphere based catalysts as the references. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of monodisperse-porous MnOx microspheres Poly(methacrylic acid-co-ethylene dimethacrylate), poly(MAA-co-EDMA) microspheres 5.3 μm in size were obtained by multi-step microsuspension polymerization using poly(glycidyl methacrylate) latex as the seed 1.8 μm in size [44]. The monodisperse-porous MnOx microspheres were synthesized by “staged shape templating protocol” using poly(MAA-co-EDMA) microspheres as the template [44]. The detailed synthesis protocol was given in the previous study [44]. Briefly, poly(MAA-co-EDMA) microspheres (4 mg mL−1) were dispersed in distilled-dionized water (DDI, 25 mL) and pH was adjusted to 8.0 with 0.5 M NH4OH. KMnO4 was added into the aqueous dispersion at a final concentration of 20 mg mL−1 and the final pH was checked. The mixture was stirred at 350 rpm for 24 h at room temperature for the adsorption of MnOx nanoparticles onto the poly(MAA-co-EDMA) microspheres. HNO3 solution (3.5 mL 20 % w/w) was added dropwise to the aqueous dispersion within 1 min and the final dispersion was stirred for 24 h. The composite microspheres were washed several times with 1 % w/w aqueous sodium dodecyl sulphate (SDS) solution and DDI water to remove sub-micron MnOx particles from the aqueous dispersion containing MnOx/polymethacrylate microspheres ca. 4.0 μm in size. The microspheres were isolated by centrifugation at 4000 rpm for 5 min and dried at 85 °C under vacuum for 24 h. To obtain monodisperse-porous MnOx microspheres, the polymethacrylate template was removed by the calcination of composite microspheres at 410 or 500 °C for 4 h, under air atmosphere, with a heating rate of 1 °C min-1. 2.2 Synthesis of monodisperse-porous SiO2 and TiO2 microspheres SiO2 and TiO2 microspheres in the monodisperse-porous form were also synthesized via corresponding staged shape templating sol-gel protocols by starting with poly(MAA-co-EDMA) and poly(3-chloro-2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate-co-ethylene dimethacrylate) (poly(HPMA-Cl-co-EDMA) microspheres 5.3 μm and 5.4 μm, respectively, in size as the templates. These protocols were described in our previous publications in detail [45–48]. These protocols were given briefly in Sections 2.1 and 2.2 of the Supporting Information. 2.3 Derivatization of monodisperse-porous MnOx microspheres Prior to decoration with Pd NPs, monodisperse-porous MnOx microspheres were derivatized with amino groups. For this purpose, dry MnOx microspheres were dispersed in a solution containing isopropanol (Iso-PrOH, 10 mL), 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES, 1 mL) and triethylamine (TEA, 0.15 mL) by vortexing in a sealed glass reactor. The reactor was placed in a shaking water bath at 80 °C for 24 h. Amino functionalized-MnOx microspheres were extensively washed with Iso-PrOH and DDI water for several times. The same protocol was also applied for monodisperse-porous SiO2 and TiO2 microspheres for obtaining Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2 catalysts. 2.4 Decoration of Pd NPs onto amino functionalized-MnOx microspheres For attachment of Pd NPs onto amino functionalized-MnOx microspheres, Pd NPs were synthesized according to the method given in the literature [29]. PVA solution (10 mg mL−1, 0.3 mL) was added to Pd(NO3)2·2H2O solution (3 mg in 10 mL) and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 15 min. Then, freshly prepared 0.1 M NaBH4 solution (1.2 mL) was added rapidly to the above solution and the stirring was continued for 1 h at room temperature. Amino functionalized-MnOx microspheres (0.1 g) were added into the previous mixture and pH was adjusted to 3.0 with H2SO4, and the mixture was stirred for another 1 h. Pd NPs decorated monodisperse-porous MnOx microspheres (Pd@MnOx) were washed with DDI water for 3 times by centrifugation-decantation. The same protocol was also followed for the attachment of Pd NPs onto amino functionalized forms of monodisperse-porous SiO2 and TiO2 microspheres. 2.5 Benzyl alcohol oxidation The catalytic activity of Pd NPs decorated monodisperse-porous manganese oxide microspheres (Pd@MnOx) were investigated by oxidation of BzOH. In these runs, Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2 catalysts were also used. Typically, the catalyst (Pd@MnOx microspheres or other catalysts, 80 mg) was dispersed in diethyleneglycol dimethylether (DEGDME, 10 mL) containing BzOH (0.1 mL) and TBHP (0.15 mL) in a two-necked flask (50 mL). The flask was immersed in an oil bath and heated to 80 °C under magnetic stirring for a certain period. A small volume of sample (100 μL) was withdrawn from flask at appropriate intervals and analyzed using a High-Pressure Liquid Chromatography (HPLC, Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with UV detector (SPD-10AV, Shimadzu, Japan) and a Phenomenex SphereClone 5 μm Silica (250 × 4.60 mm 5 μm) column. BzOH conversion and BzCHO selectivity were calculated as follows: (1) BzOH conversion % = C o − C B z O H C o × 100 (2) BzCHO selectivity % = C B z H C o − C B z O H × 100 C0 is the initial concentration of BzOH. CBzOH and CBzCHO are the concentrations of BzOH and BzCHO at a certain reaction time, respectively. The turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF) of catalysts were calculated according to the procedure given in Section 4 of the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts In our previous work, it was demonstrated that the crystal structure of MnOx microspheres produced by “staged shape templating protocol” had different chemical compositions depending on calcination temperature [44]. By considering this property, two different MnOx based catalysts were prepared, using MnOx microspheres calcined at 410 and 500 °C as the support. X-ray diffraction spectra (XRD) of Pd@MnOx microspheres synthesized using plain MnOx microspheres calcined at 410 °C and 500 °C are given in Fig. 1 . Pd@MnOx microspheres synthesized using MnOx calcined at 410 °C contained monoclinic Mn5O8 (97 %) and Mn98O2 (3 %) phases (space group 12: C12/m1, unique-b, cell-1, JCPDS Card No. 39-1218) (Fig. 1A). On the other hand, tetragonal α-MnO2 (71 %) and Mn2O3 (bixbyite, 29 %) phases were observed in the other catalyst obtained using MnOx calcined at 500 °C (space group I4/m, JCPDS data file 00-044-0141) (Fig. 1B) [44]. By considering the predominant crystalline phase in the support, the catalysts prepared with MnOx microspheres calcined at 410 and 500 °C were named as Pd@Mn5O8 and Pd@MnO2 microspheres, respectively. XRD data of the used Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres after BzOH oxidation is also included in Fig. 1C for comparison. XRD pattern of the used catalyst showed that no significant change occurred in the crystalline structure after oxidation reaction. This finding might be evaluated as an indication for the stability of Pd@Mn5O8 catalyst in BzOH oxidation reaction. The chemical route followed for the synthesis of monodisperse-porous Pd@MnOx microspheres is given in Fig. 2 . The surface hydroxyl groups of monodisperse-porous MnOx microspheres coming from manganese hydroxide residues were reacted with APTES in Iso-PrOH using TEA as the catalyst. Pd NPs were obtained by the reaction of Pd(NO3)2·2H2O with NaBH4 in the existence of PVA as the stabilizer. The TEM photograph of free Pd NPs obtained in the absence of MnOx microspheres, given in Fig. 3 showed that Pd NPs were obtained in the range of 2−4 nm, with an average size of 2.6 nm, by the applied synthetic protocol. The variation of zeta potential of Pd NPs with pH is also given in Fig. 3. The minimum negative charge on Pd NPs was obtained at pH 3.0. The attachment of Pd NPs onto Mn5O8 microspheres functionalized with amino groups was investigated by changing the pH of attachment medium between 3–7 and the highest catalytic activity in BzOH oxidation was obtained with Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres obtained at pH 3.0. For this reason, the attachment of Pd NPs onto amino functionalized-MnOx (i.e. MnO2 or Mn5O8) microspheres was performed at pH 3.0. Note that, Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2 microspheres were also obtained by the same route given in Fig. 2, using amino functionalized forms of corresponding metal oxide microspheres. The SEM photographs showing size distribution and surface morphology of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres and TEM-EDS mapping photographs showing the composition of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres are exemplified in Fig. 4 . As seen in Fig. 4A, the particles were obtained in spherical and almost monodisperse form. The mean size and the coefficient of variation (CV) for size distribution were calculated as 3.85 μm and 5.87 %, respectively, based on the SEM photo given in Fig. 4A (Table 1 ). A rough surface was observed on the microspheres likely due to their porous structure (Fig. 4B–D). The mean size and CV values of MnO2 microspheres obtained with the calcination at 500 °C are also given in Table 1. Palladium (purple), manganese (green), oxygen (blue) and carbon (red) can be clearly seen in TEM-EDS photograph of Pd@Mn5O8 microsphere in Fig. 4E. Also as seen Fig. 4F, Pd NPs were homogeneously distributed on Mn5O8 microspheres. The TEM-EDS photographs showing manganese (green) and oxygen (blue) are also given in Fig. 4G and H, respectively. The SEM photographs of Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2 microspheres obtained by the same synthesis route are given in Fig. 5 . These microspheres were also obtained in the monodisperse form, with the surface morphologies similar to Pd@MnOx microspheres. As seen in Table 1, the mean size and the CV values obtained for Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2 microspheres are close to those of Pd@MnOx microspheres. The pore-size distribution curves of Pd@MnOx, Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2 microspheres obtained by nitrogen adsorption-desorption method are given in Fig. 6 . The pore-size distributions of all catalysts are in the range of 3−140 nm. The porous characteristics of Pd@MnOx, Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2 microspheres are presented in Table 1. Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2 microspheres had relatively higher specific surface area and higher pore volume with respect to MnOx based catalysts. Nitrogen physisorption isotherms of all catalysts are given in Fig. S1 of the Supporting Information. All isotherms exhibited a hysteresis loop with type IV isotherm behavior showing the presence of dominantly mesoporous structure for all catalysts. However, all catalysts also included macroporous volume as shown in their pore-size distributions (Fig. 6). The highest surface area was obtained with Pd@SiO2 catalysts with the lowest mean pore size and the highest pore volume. The mean pore size values of MnO2, Mn5O8 and TiO2 based catalysts were close to 40 nm (Table 1). The lower surface areas of MnO2 and Mn5O8 based catalysts can be explained by their lower pore volumes (i.e. lower porosities) with respect to TiO2 based catalyst (Table 1). Pd atom contents of Pd@SiO2, Pd@TiO2, and Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres were determined as 2.5, 2.5 and 1.6 % w/w respectively, by ICP-MS. Hence, all catalysts synthesized using different metal oxide microspheres had close Pd NP contents. Also the Pd atom content of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres after the oxidation reaction was determined as 1.65 %. This means that Pd content of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres did not change after the catalytic reaction. The results obtained from the characterization part indicated that Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2 microspheres could be used for comparison to evaluate the catalytic performance of Pd@MnOx microspheres in oxidation of BzOH due to their similar size and porous properties and close Pd NP contents. The survey XPS spectra of MnO2, Mn5O8, APTES attached Mn5O8 (APTES@Mn5O8) and Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres are given in Fig. 7 . Mn2p, O1s and C1s peaks were obtained at 642, 529 and 284.5 eV, respectively, in the survey XPS spectra of MnO2 and Mn5O8 microspheres given in Fig. 7A and B, respectively. The surface atomic compositions of MnO2, Mn5O8, APTES@Mn5O8 and Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres determined by XPS analysis are presented in Table 2 . Si2p and N1s peaks were observed at the binding energies of 101 and 401 eV, respectively, in the survey XPS spectrum of APTES@Mn5O8 microspheres due to the bound APTES (Fig. 7C). In addition to these peaks, a clear Pd3d peak at 337.1 eV was obtained for Pd NPs on the surface of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres (Fig. 7D). The presence of APTES on the surface was more clearly shown in the core level spectrum of N1s scan for APTES@Mn5O8 microspheres (Fig. S2A of the Supporting Information). A N1s peak with lower intensity was also obtained in the corresponding core-level spectrum of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres (Fig. S2B of the Supporting Information). Based on the survey XPS spectrum of APTES@Mn5O8 microspheres, the surface N and Si atom contents were determined as 2.48 and 2.63 %, respectively (Table 2). The characteristic peaks at 337.1 and 342.4 eV were obtained in the core level, Pd3d scan with Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres (Fig. 7E). Pd atom content of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres was determined as 3.30 % according to the survey XPS spectra given in Fig. 7. Metallic Pd usually provides a peak at the binding energy of 335.4 eV [49]. Small shifts up to 0.9 eV may occur in the binding energy of metallic Pd by the variation of its electronegativity due to the binding onto a metal oxide support [49]. However in our case, the main peak belonging to Pd was observed at 337 eV. The relatively higher shift may be attributted to the partial oxidation of Pd NPs bound onto Mn5O8 based support (Table 2). The deconvoluted peak at 337.15 cm−1 in the core-level spectrum of Pd3d scan can be evaluated as another evidence showing the partial oxidation of Pd NPs on Mn5O8 microspheres (Fig. 7E). The core level spectra for O1s scan of MnO2, Mn5O8, APTES@Mn5O8 and Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres are given in Fig. S3 of the Supporting Information. Sharp O1s peaks at 529.5 eV belonging to lattice oxygen were obtained in the O1s spectra of MnO2 and Mn5O8 microspheres (Fig. S3A and S3B). An apparent deconvoluted peak was observed at 531.6 eV near the sharp peak belonging to lattice oxygen in the O1s spectrum of APTES@Mn5O8 microspheres due to surface bound oxygen atoms coming from APTES (Fig. S3C). The same peak was stronger in the O1s spectrum of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres due to additional contribution coming from the oxygen atoms found in the partially oxidized Pd NPs attached onto the surface (Fig. S3D). The small deconvoluted peak at 533.5 eV [i.e. O(III)] was associated with adsorbed water [50]. FTIR-ATR spectra of Mn5O8, APTES@Mn5O8 and Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres are given in Fig. S4 of the Supporting Information. The strong band at 3680 cm−1 in the FTIR-ATR spectrum of Mn5O8 microspheres was assigned to OH stretching originated from manganese hydroxide residues (Fig. S4A). The presence of APTES on Mn5O8 microspheres was confirmed by the bands at at 3300, 1580, 1380 and 1020 cm−1 assigned to NH stretching, NH bending, CH bending and CN stretching, respectively (Fig. S4B). The relative intentities of these bands considerably decreased by the attachment of Pd NPs onto the surface of Mn5O8 microspheres (Fig. S4C). The thermal stability and the phase transformation of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres were investigated in the temperature range of 0−800 °C with a ramp of 10 °C /min. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve is given in Fig. S5 of the Supporting Information. The first weight-loss which can be attributed to the release of bound water molecules was observed up to 300 °C [51]. The weight-loss after 600 °C was due to the reduction of Mn5O8 to Mn3O4 by releasing oxygen. This means that Mn5O8 structure is stable up to 600 °C [52]. The exposed surface area of active sites and active particle diameter was measured by carbon monoxide (CO) chemisorption analysis as 105.4 m²/g metal and 4.7 nm, respectively. CO chemisorption analyses were performed for both plain Mn5O8 and Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres. The comparison of mean size values of free and immobilized Pd NPs demonstrated that no significant aggregation for Pd NPs occurred on Mn5O8 microspheres during immobilization (i.e. 2.6 nm, Fig. 3). Helium-temperature programmed desorption (He-TPD) profiles were obtained to analyze the desorption of CO from the surfaces of the tried catalysts (Fig. S6 of the Supporting Information). It is clear that the desorption peak positions and the TCD signal intensity obtained on Mn5O8 microspheres are significantly lower than on Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres, showing that most probably CO was physisorbed on Mn5O8 microspheres, while it was chemisorbed on Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres, as expected. The strong desorption peak at 296 °C in Fig. S6B could not be observed for Mn5O8 microspheres in Fig. S6A, which was most probably associated with the desorption of chemisorbed CO from Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres. 3.2 Catalytic performance of Pd@MnOx microspheres in BzOH oxidation The conversion of BzOH, the selectivity and the formation yield of BzCHO obtained with Pd@SiO2, Pd@TiO2 and Pd@MnOx microspheres are comparatively given in Fig. 8 . In these runs, Pd NPs immobilized forms of monodisperse-porous SiO2 and TiO2 microspheres calcined at 410 °C were used for comparison. BzOH conversions lower than 15 % were obtained when plain Mn5O8 and plain MnO2 microspheres were used as the catalyst. Considerably higher BzOH conversions and BzCHO formation yields were obtained with Pd@MnO2 and Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres (i.e. MnOx based catalysts) with respect to those of Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2 microspheres (Fig. 8). Here, it should be noted that the surface areas and the pore volumes of Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2 microspheres were considerably higher with respect to MnOx based catalysts (Table 1). On the other hand, overall BzOH conversion and BzCHO formation yield obtained with Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres were higher with respect to those of Pd@MnO2 microspheres. To sum up, the highest catalytic activity was obtained with Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres although its surface area and pore volume were considerably lower among the tried catalysts (Table 1 and Fig. 8). Based on these results, it is hypothesized that the interaction between microspheres as support and nanoparticles as catalytic active center should remarkably influence the resulting catalytic activity, in addition to the morphological properties of microspheres. The synergistic interaction between catalytic active center and support is likely the reason of higher catalytic activity particularly when reducible metal oxides such as MnOx and TiO2 with higher oxygen spillover capability, creating more reactive sites that are rich in oxygen are used as the support [29,53]. On the other hand, the higher synergistic catalytic activity obtained with MnOx based catalysts with respect to TiO2 based one may be related to the difference between the crystalline structures of MnOx and TiO2 microspheres [54,55]. The higher BzCHO formation yield obtained with Pd@TiO2 with respect to Pd@SiO2 may be also explained by the formation of a synergistic effect between Pd NPs and TiO2 microspheres. Although SiO2 microspheres have a large (i.e. the highest) surface area that may also reduce the risk of agglomeration of immobilized Pd NPs on the microspheres, the lowest BZCHO formation yield is obtained with Pd@SiO2 likely due to no synergistic effect occurs between Pd NPs and amorphous SiO2 microspheres. In order to demonstrate the mixed valence nature of MnOx based catalysts, the core level spectra for Mn2p scan of MnO2, Mn5O8, APTES@ Mn5O8 and Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres are comparatively given in Fig. 9 . The surface percentages of Mn(II), Mn(III) and Mn(IV) determined by deconvoluted core-level spectra for Mn2p scan with MnO2, Mn5O8, APTES@Mn5O8 and Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres are given in Table 2. The analysis of XPS spectra clearly showed the presence of multiple oxidation states of manganese on both Mn5O8 and MnO2 microspheres, capable of generating oxidative oxygen species in the presence of O2. The oxygen vacancies on MnOx microspheres potentially create a suitable platform for obtaining a synergistic interaction between the support and the active center for the activity of synthesized catalyst in BzOH oxidation [50]. The transfer of oxidative oxygen species from MnOx (i.e. support) to Pd NPs (i.e. active center) increases the catalytic activity. The sum of Mn(II) and Mn(III) percentages was determined as 22.59 and 22.81 for MnO2 and Mn5O8 microspheres, respectively. Hence, higher catalytic activities observed with Pd@MnO2 and Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres with respect to Pd@TiO2 and Pd@SiO2 can be explained by the mixed valence nature of MnOx based supports suitable for the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies ( Fig. 8 ). On the other hand, the total intensity of the deconvoluted peaks at 641.2 and 652.9 eV belonging to Mn(II), located under the Mn2p3/2 and Mn2p1/2 peaks in the core-level Mn2p spectrum of MnO2 microspheres was slightly lower with respect to that obtained in the core level spectra for Mn2p scan of Mn5O8 based microspheres (Fig. 9A and B). For this reason, the Mn(II) percentages were determined as 1.90 and 2.92 for MnO2 and Mn5O8 microspheres, respectively (Table 2). Depending upon this property, a higher Mn(II) percentage was also obtained for Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres (Table 2). Hence, the higher catalytic activity of Pd@Mn5O8 with respect to Pd@MnO2 can be explained by the stronger synergistic interaction between Mn5O8 based support and Pd NPs due to the higher Mn(II) content of Mn5O8 microspheres which is more prone to creating oxygen vacancies on the support. On the other hand, the higher surface area and pore volume of Pd@Mn5O8 with respect to those of Pd@MnO2 should be also evaluated as another factor positively contributing to the higher catalytic activity of Pd@Mn5O8 (Table 1). Based on the above discussion, the catalytic activity based on the synergistic effect between active center and support can be ordered with respect to the catalyst type as Pd@Mn5O8>Pd@MnO2>Pd@TiO2, by considering the BzCHO formation yields in Fig. 8. Mesoporous transition metal oxides have been used in a wide range of oxidation reactions due to multiple oxidation states which are very important in electron transfer during redox catalytic reactions [56,57]. Among the transition metal oxides, manganese oxides deserve a special interest due to its easily replaceable multiple oxidation states, thermal stability, and dioxygen reduction ability [58]. The mobility of lattice oxygen make the manganese oxide materials effective catalysts in oxidation reactions [59]. The schematic representation of the mechanism proposed for the synergistic catalytic activity obtained with Pd@MnOx microspheres in BzOH oxidation is given in Fig. 10 . Mn5O8 based catalysts are the promising ones for oxidation reactions due to the mixed valence nature of Mn5O8 [60]. Moreover, the interlayer and/or intralayer defects of Mn5O8 crystalline structure may facilitate the ion transport between support and active center [60–63]. Hence, the strongest synergistic effect between Pd NPs and MnOx microspheres is potentially expected in the presence of Mn5O8. Moreover, the immobilization of Pd NPs on Mn5O8 microspheres probably assists the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies and increases the mobility of surface lattice oxygen in the BzOH oxidation. In the proposed mechanism, BzOH is adsorbed onto Pd NPs and converted to metal–alkoxide intermediate. BzCHO is formed from this intermediate and palladium hyride is formed. Hence, Pd NPs are covered by hydrogens. Oxidative oxygen species are formed by the conversion of oxygen adsorbed onto the oxygen vacancies. This formation is induced by the transformation of Mn(II) and Mn(III) to Mn(IV) in the structure of Mn5O8. Finally, the oxidative oxygen species are reacted with palladium hydride to regenerate Pd NPs. The variation of overall BzOH conversion and BzCHO formation yield with the time in the presence of Pd@MnOx, Pd@TiO2 and Pd@SiO2 microspheres is exemplified in Fig. S7A and S7B of the Supporting Information, respectively. As seen in both figures, the plateau values for BzOH conversion and BzCHO formation yield were obtained within ca. 2 h using MnOx and TiO2 based catalysts. The lowest BzOH consumption rate and the lowest BzCHO formation rate with respect to the others were obtained by using Pd@SiO2 microspheres having the highest surface area among the tried catalysts. The highest turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF) values were obtained with Pd@Mn5O8 catalyst for the reaction period of 4 h (Table 3 ). On the other hand, TOF values were also included for 1 h to have an idea about the kinetic behaviour. According to the commonly accepted mechanism of BzOH oxidation, different pathways leading to formation of different products are observed [64–67]. In two of them, BzCHO is obtained by the dehydrogenation and disproportionation via alkoxy compounds and hydrogenolysis of BzOH [67]. By considering this mechanism, the effects of oxidation conditions on overall BzOH conversion and the selectivity and formation yield of BzCHO were investigated. The effect of initial BzOH concentration on overall BzOH conversion, BzCHO selectivity and BzCHO formation yield using Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres is given in Fig. 11 A. TON and TOF values obtained with different BzOH concentrations are given in Table 4 . The overall conversion decreased with the increasing BzOH concentration. The formation possibility of carbonyl oxy/dioxy compounds decreases with the increasing concentration of BzOH concentration which results in lower final conversion of BzOH [65,68]. The highest values for BzCHO selectivity and BzCHO formation yield were obtained with the initial BzOH concentration of 100 mM. With the highest BzOH concentration, the selectivity of toluene was obtained as 16.7 % which was the highest value among the toluene selectivities in this set. The presence of more surface hydrogen was previously given as the reason of this result [65,66]. The effect of catalyst concentration on BzOH conversion and BzCHO formation yield using Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres is shown in Fig. 11B. The overall conversion increased, however, the BzCHO selectivity decreased with the increasing catalyst concentration likely due to the change occurred in reaction pathway [67]. As expected, TON and TOF values decreased with increasing amount of Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres (Table 4). The effect of Pd NPs loading onto Mn5O8 microspheres on overall BzOH conversion and BzCHO formation yield is given in Fig. 11C. Pd NPs loading of 2.5 % (w/w) with respect to Mn5O8 based microspheres was the most appropriate value providing the highest overall conversion and the highest selectivity for BzCHO. The decrease in the BzCHO formation yield with the Pd NPs loading of 5.0 % (w/w) should be likely related to the formation aggregates of Pd NPs immobilized on the surface of MnOx microspheres with the increasing concentration of Pd NPs in the attachment medium. Among the tried conditions, the highest TON and TOF values were obtained as 103.4 and 25.9 h−1 for a reaction period of 4 h with the Pd@Mn5O8 catalyst prepared with the Pd NPs loading of 1.25 % w/w ( Table 4 ). The highest TOF for this catalyst was found as 76.6 h−1 based on the reaction period of 1 h. The effect of TBHP concentration on overall BzOH conversion and BzCHO formation yield using Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres is shown in Fig. 11D. The results indicated that TBHP concentration of 150 mM was the most appropriate one for obtaining a satisfactory BzOH conversion (92.2 %) with the highest selectivity (96.3 %). The use of TBHP at lower or higher concentration resulted in an appreciable decrease in the selectivity of BzCHO. This behaviour can be explained by the variation of reaction pathway leading to different final products such as toluene and benzyl benzoate [64,66]. No signifcant change was observed both in TON and TOF within the studied range of TBHP concentration (Table 4). To compare the catalytic performance of TBHP, molecular oxygen and H2O2, the effect of oxidant type on overall BzOH conversion and BzCHO formation yield using Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres is given in Fig. S8 of the Supporting Information. The highest overall BzOH conversion and the highest BzCHO formation yield were obtained with TBHP. Both overall BzOH conversion and BzCHO formation yield markedly decreased by using molecular oxygen or H2O2 instead of TBHP. The recycling behaviour of Pd@MnOx microspheres is given in Fig. 12 . BzOH conversion and BzCHO selectivity decreased 26.2 and 11.2 %, respectively over five consecutive runs. After the first run, the decrease in the BzCHO formation yield is quite small. Based on this behaviour the reusability of Pd@MnOx microspheres in the consecutive BzOH oxidation runs may be termed as satisfactory. The comparison of Pd@Mn5O8 catalyst exhibiting the best catalytic activity among the catalysts tried in our study with the similar heterogeneous catalysts used for BzOH oxidation in different studies showed that satisfactorily high overall BzOH conversion and BzCHO selectivity were obtained with Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres (Table 5 ). 4 Conclusion The heterogeneous catalysts for the oxidation of BzOH were prepared by the immobilization of Pd NPs on monodisperse-porous metal oxide microspheres. Considerably higher catalytic activities documented with overall BzOH conversion and BzCHO formation yield were obtained with Pd@MnO2 and Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres among the tried catalysts. This behaviour was explained by the synergistic effect between Pd NPs and MnOx based support, depending upon the reducible metal oxide character of MnOx due to its mixed valence nature assisting the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies and increasing the mobility of surface lattice oxygen in the BzOH oxidation. For this purpose, deconvoluted XPS spectra were used as an effective tool for demonstrating the presence of multiple oxidation states of manganese in the synthesized catalysts. Thus, the enhacement in BzOH oxidation rate was explained by the transfer of oxidative oxygen species formed via multiple oxidation states of Mn from Mn5O8 based support to the immobilized Pd NPs as the active centers. In this study, a methodology for the synthesis of a heterogeneous catalysts with controlled size and porous properties was also exemplified. In this methodology, monodisperse-porous microspheres were synthesized as the support, by a staged shape templating protocol by choosing an appropriate couple containing a polymethacrylate template and a precursor for obtaining the desired metal oxide in the form of monodisperse-porous microspheres. The size and porous properties of resulting metal oxide microspheres can be adjusted by changing size and morphological properties of polymeric template. This methodology allows the comparison of catalytic performances of heterogeneous catalysts and the investigation of synergistic interaction between active center and support by changing either the nanoparticle or the support type and by protecting morphological properties of resulting catalysts. Monodisperse Mn5O8 microspheres with multivalence character and having a considerable surface area originated from their porous character were selected as a support for the synthesis of oxidation catalyst. The combination of selected support (i.e. Mn5O8) with an active center in the form Pd NPs provided higher catalytic activity with respect to the similar catalysts synthesized using SiO2 and TiO2 microspheres with similar mean size values, but better porous properties. As demonstrated by CO chemisorption study, the satisfactory surface area of porous Mn5O8 microspheres allowed the immobilization of Pd NPs on the selected support without occuring any significant nanoparticle aggregation. In addition to this property, the synergistic interaction between Mn5O8 based support and Pd NPs, originated from the multivalence character of the selected support, resulted in higher catalytic activity with the Pd@Mn5O8 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: A heterogeneous catalyst for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol (BzOH) was synthesized by immobilization of Pd nanoparticles (Pd NPs, 3 nm) on monodisperse-porous manganese oxide (MnOx, 4 μm) microspheres obtained by “staged shape templating protocol”. MnOx microspheres containing Mn5O8 (97 %) and MnO2 (78 %) phases were evaluated as supports. The catalysts carrying immobilized Pd NPs were also synthesized, using monodisperse-porous SiO2 and TiO2 microspheres with similar size and porous properties (i.e. Pd@SiO2 and Pd@TiO2). Pd NP decorated-Mn5O8 (Pd@Mn5O8) microspheres provided the highest catalytic activity with BzOH conversion of 92.2 % and benzaldehyde (BzCHO) selectivity of 96.3 %. Higher catalytic activity of Pd@Mn5O8 was explained by mixed valence nature of Mn5O8 microspheres assisting the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies. Mn (II), Mn(III) and Mn(IV) oxidation states were shown by deconvoluted x-ray photoelectron spectra. A synergistic catalytic activity was reported for the first time, by combination of Pd NPs with Mn5O8 microspheres. Pd@Mn5O8 microspheres could be reused up to 5 times without remarkable loss in the activity and selectivity towards BzCHO. A methodology for comparison of catalytic activity and synergistic interaction between active site and support was also exemplified by choosing a nanoparticle type and a monodisperse-porous microsphere type.
coredata.dc:title: A synergistic catalyst based on a multivalence monodisperse-porous microspheres with oxygen vacancies for benzyl alcohol oxidation
